awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Integrating Evolutionary and Mechanistic Investigation of Variation in Cooperation and Life History
awd_abstract_narration:
Cooperation is a key part of many complex animal societies, but even within close-knit groups some individuals cooperate more than others. We now know individuals may benefit from cooperation in several ways, but mechanisms underlying decisions to cooperate and variation in the amount of cooperation remain incompletely understood.  The lance-tailed manakin provides an excellent opportunity to investigate why individuals vary in cooperative behavior, and how cooperative and non-cooperative behaviors coexist.  Males of this tropical bird cooperate with non-relatives in coordinated courtship displays, but only dominant alphas mate.  Some males serve long terms (6+ years) as non-breeding betas, while others become alphas without ever being betas.  Both highly cooperative and non-cooperative males breed once alpha, but males cooperating for the average number of years have low alpha success.  This project will assess the role of territory quality, genetic variability, phenotypic plasticity and bet-hedging strategies on beta male behavior. Undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral trainees will all be involved in lab and field work in the U.S. and Panama.   This work integrates research and education by (1) implementing an international field course for undergraduates that combines involvement in long-term research with student-designed projects; (2) hosting three undergraduates for REU projects in Panama; (3) developing outreach exercises for 4th-6th graders; (4) publishing educational resources and establishing an associated webcam; and (5) establishing an educational display on the field site, visited by 8000-10,000 tourists/yr.  

This project investigates mechanisms underlying behavioral variation in cooperation in the lance-tailed manakin.  It assesses the role of ecological constraints, experimentally quantifying effects of territory quality on beta behavior, and tests three complementary hypotheses explaining the occurrence of disruptive selection:  genetic variability, phenotypic plasticity, and bet-hedging in unpredictable environments.  The project quantifies additive genetic variance in cooperation using animal models on behavioral histories of pedigreed males.  Effects of individual phenotype on life history and cooperation are investigated by measuring the relationships of condition, stress responsiveness, and telomeres (repeated nucleotides on chromosome ends, implicated as bioindicators of physiological state).  Measures of lifetime siring success will yield insights about whether cooperators reduce variance in lifetime reproductive output.  The project will train one postdoctoral researcher, at least one graduate student, and 15 postgraduates in field, laboratory, and analytical techniques.  This project provides insight into both the function of cooperation by delayed direct benefits and the forces underlying disruptive selection on behavioral phenotypes.  All data from the study will be archived at the Florida State University, and metadata associated with publications will be archived on Dryad.org.  Databases will furthermore be accessible through a data repository held at the Smithsonian developed as part of the Manakin Research Coordination Network.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The unifying goal of this CAREER award was to integrate teaching and research in the study of behavioral variation in a tropical bird, the lance-tailed manakin.  Males of this species court females in complex, two-male courtship displays, and display partners include a dominant "alpha" and subordinate "beta."  Individual betas take a supporting role in displays and do not have the chance to breed while betas, but they generally increase their chances of becoming alpha in the future.  However, roughly half of males who become alphas do not cooperate as betas before assuming a breeding role.  This project investigated why reproductive cooperation varies, and collected data from a well-monitored wild population to test hypothesized social, physiological, and evolutionary causes of this variation.  This project significantly advanced our understanding of the causes of variation in complex behavioral phenotypes and the benefits of cooperative reproduction for the dominant breeders. 

Integration of teaching and research is a primary goal of CAREER awards, and in this project this integration was accomplished by designing and executing an international field course for undergraduate students in two years, deploying a live-streaming webcam of manakin activity with supporting public content, creating longer-term research opportunities for undergraduates.  Field course students travelled to the Republic of Panama with the PI, and conducted independent research projects on the long-term field site on Isla Boca Brava while completing coursework in Experimental Biology and Tropical Behavioral Ecology.  They supplemented their own studies by designing a biodiversity fair for local primary school children, teaching ecological concepts through hands-on activities. The webcam was deployed in collaboration with Cornell Lab of Ornithology BirdCams project to ensure the broadest possible visibility, and attracted well over 500,000 views, with more than 33,000 total viewing hours and that represented engagement of viewers from >130 countries. Footage from this camera was also developed into an inquiry-based educational module on the adaptive benefits of cooperation, which was shared publically and used in undergraduate teaching, including as a tool to ease the transition to emergency online instruction at several institutions in spring 2020. 

The project supported immersive field experiences for 3 students through the Research Education for Undergraduates program, two of which presented results at national scientific conferences. It also provided data for additional undergraduate projects at FSU, including one that resulted in a peer-reviewed publication led by the undergraduate researcher. To broadly disseminate information about manakins and the research project, the research team established an educational display on the field site, a popular tourist destination; and hosted a professional film crew that recorded manakin displays for a nature documentary, "Dancing with the Birds," which reached a wide public audience. 

This project directly supported the career development of graduate research of two PhD candidates and one Master?s student, as well as one postdoctoral researcher.  The postdoc and the student who completed her PhD during the term of the project both obtained faculty positions as their next career step.  The project contributed to training early-career researchers by supporting field involvement by 16 post-baccalaureate field assistants, 9 of whom have already enrolled in or are applying for graduate programs.  Results were shared with scientific and public audiences through peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, invited seminars, and public talks on manakin behavior.


Last Modified: 11/08/2022
Modified by: Emily H Duval
